section.title: Vertical Stretches Activity
section.p: In this activity, we will continue to explore how a change to a function's formula will alter its graph. In particular, we will see the effect of multiplying the output of a function by a constant number: k\cdot f(x)
Remember that if you perform some calculation with the output of a function f, you will be performing that calculation with an expression like f(a).
In this first exercise, you will practice writing an expression for the output of a function which has been altered.

statement.p: If g is a function, write an expression which means times the output of the function, when the input is .
If f is a function, write an expression which means times the output of the function, when the input is x.

section.p: In the next exercise, you will practice interpreting function notation where the input has been altered.

set.member: \text{3 times the output, when the input is 5}

li.p: For a function g(x), what does 3\cdot g(5) calculate?
For a function f(x), what does \frac{1}{3}f(x) calculate?
The expression 3\cdot g(5) means 3 times the output when the input is 5.
All of the above. Dividing by 3 and multiplying by \frac{1}{3} are equivalent.

paragraphs.title: Effects on the graph
paragraphs.p: Now we will see how to apply these concepts to the graph of a function.

section.p: First, you will use the graph of a function to complete a table of values by altering the output.

section.p: Next, you will plot points on the graphs of functions where the output has been multiplied by a number.

li.p: The graph below shows the function y = f(x). Plot five points on the graph of y = 2f(x) by moving the five blue points to appropriate locations.

section.p: In the previous exercise, you plotted points for the functions y = 2f(x) and \frac{1}{2}f(x). This created graphs which were similar to the original function y = f(x), but whose outputs were either twice as large, or half as large as those of f(x).
This makes sense, because multiplying outside of the function f(x) by a number like 2 or \frac{1}{2}, just changes the output values — and the output values are the heights of the points.
In the next two exercises, you will continue to explore how multiplying the output of a function by a number will change the graph.

\text{The transformation a\cdot f(x) stretches or compresses the graph vertically, but f(x) + a shifts the graph up or down.}
